LOUISVILLE, Ky. (WDRB) -- Some Sellersburg Water customers are under a boil water advisory through the weekend and into next week. 

Sellersburg Water customers in Jeffersonville in the Riverside neighborhood, as well as customers on the following streets: Dogwood Road, Acorn Lane, Royal Oaks, Locust Lane, Castlewood Lane, Juniper Lane and Rio Vista Lane are under an advisory until Tuesday, Sept. 20.

Officials issued the advisory Friday after a main water line break was repaired.

KANSAS CITY, Mo. — KC Water canceled the precautionary boil water advisory on Wednesday for customers in the area of NW 64th Street to NW 78th Street, and N. Congress Ave to NW Waukomis Drive.
A water main break on Tuesday prompted water services to issue a precautionary boil advisory and caused water pressure issues in several neighborhoods and local schools in the Northland on Tuesday.

KC Water Services has issued a precautionary boil order to customers in the area of NW 64th Street to NW 78th Street, and N. Congress Avenue to NW Waukomis Drive. The advisory did not include the cities of Platte Woods or Lake Waukomis.

The Park Hill School District sent out a notification that the break affected English Landing Elementary, Lakeview Middle School, Russell Jones Education Center, Chinn Elementary and Plaza Middle School.
The school district said they have enough water for lunch and enough pressure to use restrooms. The water department is working on the issue and schools are functioning as usual.
Customers in the affected areas should continue to boil water until a cancellation notice is issued.
Under a Boil Water Advisory, it is recommended that customers follow these guidelines:
• Boil all drinking water. Tap water should be boiled vigorously for three minutes before using it to drink, cook, or prepare food. Let the water cool sufficiently before drinking.
• Ice made with un-boiled tap water should not be used for drinking purposes.
• Dishes and food contact surfaces may be disinfected using tap water that contains one teaspoon of household bleach per gallon.
<li>The tap water is safe for other purposes such as bathing
column2: however, small children should be discouraged from swallowing bath water.

COLLINSVILLE •  A boil order has been issued for parts of Collinsville.
column2: theater"" target=""_blank"">The boil order was issued after a major water main broke Monday afternoon, according to the city water department. The order remained in effect Monday night.

column1:
Officials advised residents in the affected areas to boil water for at least five minutes before drinking it or using it for cooking. 

The boil order was issued for homes within the following boundaries:

• St. Clair Avenue from South Morrison Avenue to Carl Street, including Wayne Avenue and LaVadna Court.

• Arrowhead from Henry to Apache, including Dina, Southwood Trace, Woods End, Forest Southwind, and Braidwood.

• Henry from Arrowhead to Lillian.

A water boil order has been issued for Goshen residences along Bashor Road From 2101 Bashor Road to 2303 Bashor Road and 2102 Bashor Road to 2304 Bashor Road.

Below is the city utility department's notice about the boil order:

On Sept. 18, 2016 at 10:30 p.m. the water main in the listed area above had to be shut down to repair a water main break. The Indiana Department of Environmental Management requires the Water Utility to issue a boil water order for the affected area of: Bashor Road From 2101 Bashor Road to 2303 Bashor Road and 2102 Bashor Road to 2304 Bashor Road

Once two consecutive water samples have been taken 24 hours apart and analyzed for the presence of bacteria and are found to be absent of bacteria, the boil order will be lifted. Notice of the boil order cancellation will be distributed via a customer flier to the residents affected by shutdown. For further information or to report specific service concerns, please call Mindy Kyle at the Goshen Water Department at 534-5306.

City water within the affected area should not be consumed without first following prescribed boiling procedures. The water remains safe for bathing, laundry, and restroom facilities. Cleaning dishes with a dishwasher is acceptable if it has a sanitizing cycle. Hand washed dishes should be rinse with boiled or bottled water.

JEA issues boil water advisory for some customers
JEA is advising certain customers to boil water for drinking and food preparation or to use bottled water.

Earlier Story: JEA is advising certain customers to boil water for drinking and food preparation or to use bottled water.

The utility issued the advisory as a precaution Tuesday afternoon after a water main break. The notice will remain in effect until after the problem has been repaired and after “two consecutive days of satisfactory bacteriological results have been obtained.”

Customers are advised to “bring water to a rolling boil for a minimum of one minute prior to using for drinking, food preparation, or cooking” and to “flush water lines for three minutes after water returns in order to remove any air and possible sediments from the lines.”

The advisory is for the customers in the following areas:

■ Nocatee (including residents, businesses, and schools)

■ Bartram Springs Community — South of 14538 Cherry Lake Drive W. and 14499 Cherry Lake Drive E.

■ Bartram Springs Elementary School

■ The Reserve at Bartram Springs

■ Cypress Trace Community

■ Businesses at the Promenade Plaza — Everest Lane

■ Racetrack Road — East of Bartram Park Boulevard to Philips Highway (U.S. 1)

People can call customer service for the utility at (904) 665-6000 for more information related to the advisory.

Press Release from the City of Brookfield

The Missouri Department of Natural Resources (DNR) has issued a boil water order for Brookfield, with Public Water System #MO2010105. The system is located in Linn County, Missouri. Department officials issued the order because of a complete loss of water pressure on September 14, 2016 due to a water main break affecting the entire water system. When water pressure is low, conditions exist which could allow contamination to enter the distribution system or household plumbing. When large areas of a system are involved, the probability that contamination has occurred is high. The Boil Water Order took effect on September 14, 2016, and will remain in effect until water pressure is restored and sample results indicate that no contamination is present.
Anyone served by the affected public water system should observe the following precautions:

1* Boil water vigorously for three minutes prior to use for cooking or drinking.
2* Disinfect food contact surfaces (dishes) by immersing them for at least one minute in clean tap water that contains one teaspoon of unscented household bleach per gallon of water.
3* Dispose of ice cubes and remake with water that has been boiled.
4* Continue boiling all water that is to be used for cooking or drinking until the cause of the contamination has been found and corrected.
5* Water used for bathing does not need to be boiled.
6* LET WATER COOL SUFFICENTLY BEFORE DRINKING
The Department of Natural Resources will notify the public water system when the boil order is rescinded.
For more information, call Brookfield City Hall at 660-258-7442 or contact the Missouri Department of Natural Resources –Northeast Regional Office at 660-385-8000.

<div class=""js-jwloader"" data-api=""prod"" data-autoplay=""autoplay"" data-id=""1077002360416"" data-playerid=""6918249996581"" data-site=""77"" data-station=""fl-jacksonville-WTLV-B3319"" data-type=""video"">

<span class=""inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-facebook share-button facebook"" data-tealium-share="""" data-tealium-tracker=""inline_facebook"">
<a class=""inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-twitter share-button twitter"" data-tealium-share="""" data-tealium-tracker=""inline_twitter"">

After a water main break took out water to several areas in south Duval County and north St. Johns County, a boil water advisory has been issued for a large swath of that area, including homes schools and businesses, beginning on Tuesday and continuing until the problem is corrected.

The areas affected are:
Nocatee, including residents, businesses and schools
Bartram Springs Community, south of 14538 Cherry Lake Drive W and 14499 Cherry Lake Drive E
Businesses at the Promenade Plaza, Everest Lane
Racetrack Road, east of Bartram Park Boulevard to Philips Highway

The precautionary advisory asks residents to bring their water used for drinking and food preparation to a rolling boil for at least two minutes before consumption.

Also, officials ask that customers flush water lines for three minutes after water returns in order to remove any air and possible sediments from the lines.

The order will remain in effect until the problem has been corrected and two consecutive days of satisfactory bacteriological results have been obtained, says a release from JEA.

JEA customer service can be reached at 904-665-6000.

<span class=""inline-share-btn inline-share-btn-facebook share-button facebook"" data-tealium-share="""" data-tealium-tracker=""inline_facebook"">

After a water main break took out water to several areas in south Duval County and north St. Johns County, a boil water advisory has been issued for a large swath of that area, including homes schools and businesses, beginning on Tuesday and continuing until the problem is corrected.

The areas affected are:
Nocatee, including residents, businesses and schools
Bartram Springs Community, south of 14538 Cherry Lake Drive W and 14499 Cherry Lake Drive E
Businesses at the Promenade Plaza, Everest Lane
Racetrack Road, east of Bartram Park Boulevard to Philips Highway

The precautionary advisory asks residents to bring their water used for drinking and food preparation to a rolling boil for at least two minutes before consumption.

Also, officials ask that customers flush water lines for three minutes after water returns in order to remove any air and possible sediments from the lines.

The order will remain in effect until the problem has been corrected and two consecutive days of satisfactory bacteriological results have been obtained, says a release from JEA.

JEA customer service can be reached at 904-665-6000.

BLACK BROOK — A boil-water order has been issued for Black Brook Water District 1.

The areas affected are the 12 residences near the corner of French Village Road and North Main Street, plus Family Dollar and Black Brook Senior Housing on Hopkinton Turnpike.

Water must be boiled before use to ensure its safety.
The boil-water order will remain in effect until the Clinton County Health Department has satisfactory evidence of a clear water supply.
If you have questions, call 565-4870.

Harrison Public Works director Wade Phillips said a precautionary boil-water order was issued Sunday evening for city water customers south of Vista Drive on Highway 7 South, including the Southern Hills subdivision.

The boil order is in response to a 12-inch water main break. Phillips said about 7 p.m. Sunday that water was being turned back on to the line and workers were waiting to see if the repair holds.

The boil order will be in effect until samples sent to the state Health Department show no signs of problems.

All customers in the affected areas are advised that the water may be unsafe for human consumption. Water used for drinking, cooking, making ice, brushing teeth or washing dishes should be boiled for one minute prior to use. All ice cubes should be discarded and only boiled water may be used for making ice. Bottled water may be used as an alternative.
The water leak outside Claridge on Highway 65 South was a fire line for the company and no boil order was anticipated in the area where a boil order was just lifted Friday, Phillips said.

The boil-water order has finally been lifted for people on the south end of Harrison after more than a week, Public Works director Wade Phillips said Friday afternoon.

The boil order was issued following an early morning main water line break Tuesday, Aug. 30. It affected mainly Flexsteel Industries and Claridge Products and Equipment, but other streets affected were Brown, Kitchens, Roberta, Coy, Valley View, Salmon Lane and the surrounding areas.

Phillips said this particular boil order covered one of the longest, if not the longest, periods of time in Harrison.

The first set of samples sent to the state Health Department for testing the day the water line was fixed weren’t acceptable. More samples were then taken and sent for testing.

There had been hopes the boil order would have been lifted by the following Friday, but Phillips said last weekend that the city was having a problem attaining the residual chlorine level standards set by the Health Department.

Phillips explained that warmer weather makes it harder to keep chlorine levels consistent because chlorine dissipates more quickly in higher temperatures.

Crews spent Saturday and the remainder of the Labor Day holiday weekend flushing lines and boosting chlorine levels in the system, Phillips said.

Because the first and second samples failed, Phillips said, the Health Department required a series of samples over several days.

Phillips told the Harrison City Council on Thursday night that samples sent Tuesday and Wednesday passed and he had no reason to believe a third set of samples sent Thursday would fail.

Phillips stressed that the ordeal wasn’t the Health Department being unreasonable.

He said the issue was one of caution to make sure the water supply was safe for citizens in the affected area.

column1: North Haverhill puts water boil order into effect to battle E. coli
Written by NH1 News on <time datetime=""2016-09-09"" pubdate="""">September 9, 2016 9:28 am</time>.
NORTH HAVERHILL — The town has issued a boil water order after the water tested positive for E. coli.
The order for North Haverhill, which will be in effect for an undetermined amount of time, instructs all residents to boil tap water for a least two minutes before using it.
E. coli, short for Escherichia coli, is usually harmless however some forms can cause sickness.
Possible effects of E. coli are respiratory illness, bloodstream infections, diarrhea and more, according to the CDC.
The Department of Environmental Services is working to resolve the issue.

The Fairfield Coin Club will meet Sunday, Aug. 14, at Frontier College in Fairfield.

Doors will open at 11 a.m. with a meeting and auction slated for 1:30 p.m. A raffle will be held and coin dealers will be present.

Library hosts Hogwarts event

C.E. Brehm Memorial Libary is hosting An Evening at Hogwarts.

The event will be held 6 p.m. Sept. 20 and is open to children ages 7 to 12 years old. Kids will be sorted into houses, receive a wand and house tie, and attend several different Hogwarts classes. They will also compete for the House Cup and the honor of being made Head Boy and Head Girl.
